I know the member for Gippsland, representing a rural community, very much has an interest in this. What is going to be the outcome there? What about some of the other provisional tax arrangements that might be in place? What about the arrangements associated with superannuation? Are these going to be picked up as part of the broader taxation reform process? That we do not know is the simple answer to that.

We read in the financial press today that it will be at least two monthsâ€”or at least that is what the government is sayingâ€”before the actual package is dropped. I hope it is not so long. I hope it appears a bit sooner so that we can sit back and debate the issue. The member for Gippsland has repeated a nonsense that has been stated in the House in the last couple of days when the issue of taxation reform has been debated, both in question time and on a matter of public importance, that Labor did nothing. Half of these technical amendments that we are debating here this afternoon are fixing up the taxation changes which Labor put in place.

I remind the honourable member for Gippsland, and many other people on the other side, that in 1983 the biggest growth industry in Australia was tax avoidance and bottom of the harbour tax schemes. Who fixed it up? P.J. Keating, Treasurer, Labor Party. What was the next thing that he did? He looked at what the personal income tax scales were in this country and said, `This is unfair. Most people are getting very close, with bracket creep and everything else, to the top marginal tax rate', which was 60c in the dollar. He then dropped it to 47c or 48c, and then when you add the Medicare levy you get another 1Â½c on top of that. The bottom rate was 30c in the dollar, for people in Australia who are the so-called battlers that the Prime Minister likes to talk about; now it is 20c, with a changed scale in the middle. That was tax reform of a personal tax nature and yet people say that Labor did nothing.

We then had the tax summit, and arising out of that, of course, was an options paper prepared by Treasury with the famous options A, B and C. There were various elements of a consumption tax in option C, with capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax and a whole range of the other so-called nasties. If the Treasurer of the day had not been knocked over by the Prime Minister of the day and the ACTU at the hotel up the road, that might have been put in place. That is history. That is the way of it.

As a consequence, we ended up with taxation reform sponsored by the Labor party. It saw the so-called nastiesâ€”which really are an important element of taxation revenueâ€”put in place. These reforms attacked the avoidance and minimisation areas, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, and so on. As a government we went to great pains on capital gains tax to say that we were not going to tax it on the nominal value. We were actually going to make some allowances for inflation, and all the rest of it that was tied into that. There were reforms and a carefully thought through taxation system put in place to deal with issues on the way through. That raised the issue of things like dividend imputation, so that taxes were not levied twice on businesses. We saw the business tax rate lowered to stimulate the businesses in this countryâ€”and on it went.

I simply say to those people that would argue that there was no reform under Labor that they should go back and read their history books. There was. Those on the other side of the House may not agree with it. They may not think that the crackdown on bottom of the harbour tax schemes, or tax in capital gains, or putting fringe benefits things in to knock off the free lunches by some of their mates in the Victorian parliamentâ€”these sorts of thingsâ€”were Labor reforms, but that is the way of it. That was bringing equity into the system, but it was also attacking it at the source in personal income tax rates. Those people who march around this place and say that Labor did nothing should go back and read their history a little bit.

The other thing that we have been talking a great deal about here is the issue of trusts, because it is picked up in the legislation we are debating today. It is a very important issue. As was suggested yesterdayâ€”and I think that the member for Gippsland also talked about this today, asking why Labor had not done something about itâ€”in 1995 when the size of the problem became known to the Treasurer, Ralph Willis, he did do something about it. He put a piece of legislation into the parliament to crack down on the use of trusts for tax avoidance. An election was calledâ€”we lostâ€”and it was two years down the track before the government then put in, last week, their watered down version of this issue.

My friend the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) has a bit of a smile on his face because this was an argument he used yesterday in the MPI. But it is true. It is simply a fact that it took two years before you decided you wanted to do something about itâ€”or at least the government did.

The simple fact is that the amendments here contained in the Taxation Laws (Technical Amendments) Bill 1997 go to a number of tidying up exercises that are required to give some further transparency and ease of understanding of what is required. I wish it speedy passage through the parliament.
Motion (by Mr Rocher) agreed to:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! It being 12.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: â€”My speech on the adjournment debate goes to the need for additional federal funding to complete the greater western Sydney orbital roads system and for further development of cross-regional links between employment zones and regional centres.

speech.para: The completion of this roads network is to allow full development of industry in western Sydney and to ensure that this region benefits economically both during and after the Olympic Games. The federal government has recognised the western Sydney orbital between the M2 at Seven Hills and the M5 at Preston as part of the future national highway link through Sydney. As such, its funding is the responsibility of the federal government.

The western Sydney orbital is estimated to cost $800 million to build to a national highway standard with divided carriageways and graded, separated intersections over its 43-kilometre length. The previous federal government in its May 1995 budget committed $260 million to commence construction of the first stage of the western Sydney orbital between Prestons and Cecil Park. Construction was to start in 1996. Additionally, in August 1995 the then federal minister for transport committed $220 million for the second stage of the western Sydney orbital between Cecil Park and the M4 at Eastern Creek. Construction was to start in 1998.

The present federal government has reneged on that commitment. In November 1996 the then federal Minister for Transport and Regional Development, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), announced that the federal government had set aside only $109 million, over five years, towards restructuring works comprising environmental assessment, land acquisition and other planning activities.

Based on advice from the federal minister at around that time, the New South Wales government has included $7 million in the New South Wales budget for the western Sydney orbital in 1997-98. However, the federal minister has yet to announce the funding allocated for this project for that 1997-98 period.

The completion of economic development of a region is affected by the capacity and efficiency of the existing transport network to service commercial vehicles and freight movements. Greater western Sydney has a population of 1.6 million people. It has a gross national product of $35 million and produces 10 per cent of New South Wales's agricultural output, yet it has not one freeway standard cross-regional road.

Road transport is the major contributor to the distribution industry. New and expanding industries are increasingly seeking proximity to major road networks to reduce transport costs. Development in technology also leads to companies locating near other industries and local markets rather than close to their own headquarters.

The existing road network out from Sydney's metropolitan CBD is radial and lacks direct cross-regional links between employment zones and regional centres. High levels of congestion are increasingly being experienced on the existing freight corridors serving greater western Sydney, including the M4, the M5 and Cumberland highways. The capacity of the M4 has already reached 4,200 vehicles at peak hour traffic times.

This congestion is threatening the competitiveness of industry and commerce located in greater western Sydney due to insufficient freight movements and longer transport travel times. If real industrial and commercial development is to be achieved, attention needs to be paid to the movement of freight both within greater western Sydney and to the major terminals at Port Botany and Kingsford Smith airport and to the rail terminals at Chullora and Enfield.

There is also a need to take into account the likely trends in freight demand based on both future industrial growth and changes in freight activity such as just-in-time, centralised distribution, cross-docking, outsourcing of transport and distribution processes, smart warehousing and electronic trading.

The region's business community has identified the completion of what is termed the arterial road grid consisting of the existing M4, the Cumberland Highway, both Windsor Road and Old Windsor Road, the M2 under construction, the planned M5 East, and the western Sydney orbital as essential for western Sydney's economic development.
Finally, this clearly means that the federal government has to add additional finance to complete this work.

talk.start.para: â€”The introduction of Job Network on 1 May will give job seekers far more choices in selecting job referral centres and a greater opportunity to match employment with their aptitude. In Melbourne's eastern suburbs we have been well served by the employment initiatives of the Howard government.

speech.para: Apprenticeships and training programs have been brought back from the dead after 13 years of Labor neglect and my electorate of Deakin has benefited greatly from these increased vocational opportunities.

Job Network will expand upon gains already made by this government in helping people find work. For too long the unemployed were treated like products riding a conveyor belt on a production line. If one passed all the checks along the way, there was a slim possibility of a job at the end of the line.

For the many who did not make it to the end, there would be training programs where long-term unemployed without skills for the work force were directed toward positions for which they may or may not have been suited. But more importantly for the ALP and the former employment minister Beazley, they had them off the books of long-term unemployed.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the retraining gurus got their money whether there were successful job outcomes or not. Everyone was a winner, except the unemployed who genuinely wanted work. Constituents in the electorate of Deakin have consistently made two points to me when telling me about their treatment as job seekers: firstly, they had little or no contact for months with their case manager and secondly, their time was being wasted by attending compulsory group sessions. The minimum level of assistance was all they received. We believe that people deserve better and Job Network in itself, will become a departure from Labor's failed policies that delivered programs but no jobs.

Job Network is also a timely recognition that new ground must be broken to drag down unemployment levels and the time spent between jobs. With the organisations that will comprise the Job Network, the pay-off will come at the same time that it comes for their client: when that client is placed in a job. This should ensure that there are significant efforts on behalf of each client.

I am pleased to inform the unemployed in Deakinâ€”the seven per cent according to the December figuresâ€”that many of the Job Network providers have considerable experience in placing people in positions. Deakin and Melbourne's east will be well served by the network. The 10 providers judged the most suitable have been Inner East Group Training; Connect Employment and Trading Services; Job Support Vic; Mission Australia; Indo-Chinese Employment Service; Salvation Army; AHEIC Chandler; Melbourne East Group Training; Employment National, which is the revamped CES; and KYM, which is the amalgamation of three skillshare providers in the eastern suburbsâ€”Yarra Ranges, Krest and Merit of Ringwood. Of those 10 job providers who won contracts for the eastern suburbs, five are existing local providers.

To those who tendered and missed out, opportunities exist for subcontracting to the winning providers. I note, Mr Deputy Speaker, with interest that Saturday's press featured in its employment pages an advertisement from Melbourne East Group Training, a very reputable and well-known organisation in the eastern suburbs. They were calling on applications for 49 positions, including field staff, customer service personnel, job club leaders and administrative assistants. No doubt, the other organisations will also be looking for new personnel to serve their clientele.

These changes will provide a level of service and opportunity not before offered to job seekers. Job matching, job search training, intensive assistance, new enterprise schemes and apprenticeship and training services are the types of services which will be available for those hunting for a job. Of course, this comes on top of the very successful job pathway program in the eastern suburbsâ€”$348,000, the largest job pathway program in the country. They are very close to meeting their targets by the end of April. It comes on top of the one-stop shop in Ringwood, the only one-stop shop that actually looks after the needs of the young kids as well as serving the needs of the employers. They are very successful programs that have been initiated by this government.

In the very near future, I will be hosting a meeting of all of these providers to find ways in which we can work together to maximise the impact of the scheme. Mr Deputy Speaker, all these providers should be congratulated and I will certainly be endeavouring to work with them in partnership as I have done in the past two years. I congratulate them and look forward to continued successful outcomes for the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”The failure of the federal government to reach an adequate Medicare agreement with the states and the territories has to be one of the major concerns to this nation. The Premier of Queensland called the government's funding offer a `son of dud'. The Premier of Victoria called it `totally unrealistic and very unfair'. The Premier of Western Australia said he would cause the Prime Minister `a political problem' if he did not increase his offer. The Premier of New South Wales said that John Howard was `treating Australians with contempt'.

speech.para: We have heard in broad terms how dramatically the Howard government's obstinate refusal to compromise on this issue will affect the public health systems of the states and the territories. What does it mean to the health professionals on the ground? What does it mean from hospital to hospital, from patient to patient? It means longer waiting queues for surgery and care. It means people will not get the best treatment that our world-class public hospital system is capable of giving. They will not have access to the most advanced technologies and medicines. It means health professionals will be run even more ragged trying to give people a higher standard of care without the necessary financial support. It means bed closures; it means ward closures; it means hospital closures.

The human cost of the Howard government's failure on public health funding will be heavy. In my own state of New South Wales, an estimated 400 people per day are dropping out of private health insurance. This presents an annual cost to the state's hospital system of $260 million. The current Medicare agreement states that, for every two per cent fall in the amount of people holding private health insurance, an equal adjustment in funding should take place. Not only has the current federal government not lived up to this agreement, but it has directly cut funding to the New South Wales public hospitals by another $34 million.

To make up for the thousands leaving private health care the New South Wales government needs an extra $350 million a year to take the strain off the public health system. The Howard government has offered them a mere $17 million. Yet while this is happening before our very eyes, this Howard government continues to throw $600 million a year down the drain at a failed scheme to coax Australians into maintaining or picking up private health cover. With 66,000 people dropping out of private health in the three months to December, it is obvious that the scheme has been an unmitigated disaster.

The Howard government's failure on health is beginning to have a dramatic effect in my part of western Sydney. Those constituents of mine who are now seeking public health care have three major choices in our area: Liverpool Hospital, Fairfield Hospital or Westmead Hospital. All three are fine health establishments. The children's ward of Westmead especially is known for its standard of care throughout the world. However, despite the fact that the New South Wales government has now ploughed an extra $1 billion into the health system over the last three years, hospital waiting lists are increasing and will increase more because the Howard government cannot see fit to provide adequate funds for public health care.

Fairfield Hospital now needs an extra $3 million per year, which is just enough money to cater for the 1,251 extra people they are expected to have to care for as more and more people from our community leave private health cover. Liverpool Hospital needs an extra $8 million to cope with the 3,320 extra patients that are expected to be coming through its doors in the next 12 months. Westmead Hospital needs over $20 million to look after the extra 7,862 patients who will now be dependent on its care. The predicament facing these three public hospitals serving my community is very real and very desperate. The Howard government must bring itself to understand the human cost of its failure to provide the adequate funds needed under the Medicare agreement.

As the premiers displayed at their conference last Friday, this is an issue that crosses party boundaries. It is about health and is about the care of all Australians. The longer the Howard government fails to see that the more people in my community and communities like it across Australia will continue to suffer.

In the very limited time I have left to me I would also like to bring to the attention of the House that we have also experienced the closure of two more Medicare offices in my electorate. The Medicare offices at Marylands and Cabramatta have been closed by this government. We are looking now at a population of over 1.1 million for whom the only Medicare office between Liverpool and Parramatta is in my own area of Fairfield. The queues are excessive and the staff are doing an excellent job. I congratulate them for handling the business that is now coming to them. It is a disgrace. These offices were closed without any proper consideration given to how it was going to affect the people. This, on top of what is happening to our public health system, is something that this government must bow its head in shame about.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to speak about the Makin Tough on Drugs campaign which was officially launched in my electorate on Wednesday 18 March 1998. We all know that our most important resource for our nation's future is our children. As a parent of three children, I am very concerned and disturbed about the extent of the drug problem in our community. However, I believe that the war has not been lost as some try to suggest. It is up to us as a community to work collaboratively. As we all know, one of the best ways to deal with the issue of the misuse of drugs is to educate not only our children in schools but also our families at home. It is the Tough on Drugs package which will deliver this education to the community.

speech.para: Senator the Hon. Nick Minchin, Special Minister of State, and I have undertaken to implement a drug education campaign within Makin, with the aim of reducing the number of illicit drugs in our schools and the demand for illicit drug use among school children. The launch was a very important day for everyone in Makin. Among the guests were the South Australian Minister for Police, Emergency Services and Correctional Services, the Hon. Ian Evans; Senator Grant Chapman; Mrs Jill Grove, from the Drug and Alcohol Services Council; and Sergeant Bob Kemp from the Para Hills police station, who addressed the issues surrounding drugs in our community and the adverse effects of drug use.

It was also a delight to have in attendance representatives from many of the churches, community groups and organisations within Makin and, most importantly, the SRC representatives who attended from schools across the electorate. Channel 9 Adelaide identity Xavier Minniecon hosted the launch, which also featured the local band Cabinet, who delivered a strong message about the use of drugs and peer pressure, particularly among school children.

At this point I would like to acknowledge the outstanding work over many years and the achievements that have already been made in the area of drug awareness and education, not only by our schools councils but by programs being run by our service clubs, such as the Lions Drug Awareness Foundation and the Rotary International Drug Abuse Prevention Committee. I am also aware of the work being done by Apex Clubs in their research for the prevention of youth suicide, which research does suggest has a link with the misuse of drugs, both legal and illicit.

Prior to the launch of the Tough on Drugs campaign I had the pleasure of meeting with all of the school principals in my electorate to discuss the launch. All of the principals stated that further funding for the program was a necessity, as well as teacher-friendly packages for the implementation of the program. I am happy to report that the Makin community have welcomed the announcement from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) of a further $100 million for the national Tough on Drugs campaign for treatment, counselling and education.

Our teachers and school community in general have, over the past decade or so, carried the tremendous burden of an overcrowded curriculum, to the extent that our society expects so much from our teachersâ€”from teaching our children, literally, to tie their shoelaces, to improving their socialisation skills and a myriad other skills that were once part of family education in the home. Overall, teachers do a great job. When I visit our schools I am constantly amazed at the extraordinary talent and abilities of our students, which have been fostered and nurtured by our teachers and for which they must take credit.

However, in relation to drug education it is now time for our parents and families to take a proactive role by taking ownership of the problems facing our kids and talking to their children about drug use. As a community we need to take responsibility for our children and not expect our schools to tackle the problem on their own. Senator the Hon. Nick Minchin and I will be co-sponsoring parent information nights across the electorate of Makin over the coming weeks and months, so that parents can become much more involved and informed of the services available to them.

As I have said, the war against drugs is not lost. In Makin we have commenced a full frontal assault because our kids are worth the effort. I commend the Prime Minister for his stance on family values and his Tough on Drugs campaign.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise on the adjournment today to talk a little bit about codes of conduct and what they actually mean. Codes of conduct have been in the news a fair bit during the term of this government. I have had some trouble defining code of conduct, given that the question of what the code itself actually is has altered considerably in the time of this government.

speech.para: Initially, I thought the code of conduct related to guidelinesâ€”rules, if you likeâ€”for ministerial responsibility and under what circumstances and in what way a minister should act on the question of propriety. But I have decided that it is now not that at all. I think I have really understood it. The wording is not `code of conduct', but actually `in code of conduct'. The code is the issue. It is not the conduct; it is the code.

It is a bit like a Cheshire cat. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, recall in your youthâ€”not that long agoâ€”Alice in Wonderland and the Cheshire cat. The Cheshire cat said, `Words are what I mean them to mean, not what I say, what I mean them to mean.' The circumstances change on an ongoing basis. I think we are in a land where there are many Cheshire cats. But the king of the cats at the moment is, I think, the Prime Minister on this issue of the question of what the code is.

The other thing is whether this code should be a written code of conduct. I have pondered that as well, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I have decided it should not be. Maybe it should be on a tape or on a CD, sort of like in Mission Impossible. I am sure we all recall Mission Impossible, the series, where Jim Phelps would go along to a bus stop or a park and he would come across a tape machine. He would turn it on, and the tape would play and tell him something. I suspect in the case of this government the tape would say something along the lines of, `Your ministry, should you choose to accept it, is to be resources, transport, small business, administrative services, assistant treasurer,' et cetera. `Of course, if you, or any member of your administrative team are apprehended, the Prime Minister will deny all knowledge, all responsibility, for your actions. Good luck, Jim. This tape will self-destruct in five seconds.' Let us face it, the tape took five seconds to self-destruct, which is a bit longer than it took for the Code of Conduct under this government.

But then, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said, and we have seen this develop over time, as a code of conduct it started off as `This is the new way forward.' This was the new, better standard, including steak knives! Then it went to a situation where it was very similar to the standard practised by previous governments but with some improvements. It went on from there to being the same. I am a bit worried, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if this government goes on much longer, the circumstances may well be that it is actually something beyond thatâ€”that it will go back further than that to a situation where it is something akin to the last century. It is only a matter of time.

When I look at some of the ministers who have gone already, I do express quite a bit of sympathy. I want to stress that I know a number of the people who have in fact paid the price with respect to the Code of Conduct. I, for one, and I think it is true of most, do not question their integrity but neither do I question the fact that they have breached the Code of Conduct. When you set a high jump, and you set a level that must be passed, people have to pay the price when they fail it. But certainly, Jim Short, amongst others, was unlucky in the circumstances. I think one person who has been very lucky has been the current Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer), who I also know quite well and have a lot of time for. But there is no doubt that he is in breach. I am sure that Jim Short, who is in London now, will be looking down here and wondering what the fuss is all about, and probably in his own way is happy.

talk.start.para: â€”On a point of order, the honourable member opposite cast a reflection on the Ministerâ€”
â€”Which minister?

â€”The Minister for Resources and Energy. He said that the minister was `in breach'. The Prime Minister has said that the minister is not in breach. There are forms of the House that the member can use if he wishes to make allegations.
â€”I did not hear the actual words that the member for Bruce is charged with using. I do admonish him to stick to the standing orders, which I am sure he will try and do.

â€”I will stick to the standing orders, Mr Deputy Speaker, much better than the minister has stuck to the Code of Conduct. Certainly, I find it interesting that John Howard's statementsâ€”(Time expired)

â€”The speech I am about to read was written for me by young Lachlan Kay who is a year 10 student at Sandgate High School. Lachlan has also been nominated Youth Governor of Queensland. Over the past six months I have been working with a group of young people in my electorate who have now formed a task force. This group of eight young people, after several meetings with me, decided that it would be beneficial to hold a forum for the youth in my electorate in which they could express their views on issues that are relevant to them. The task force, with my assistance, will now hold a youth forum which they have called the Lilley Youth Conference. It will be on 5 April at one of the local high schools. The youth attending will range in age from 15 to 25. The task force has recognised four main issues to be discussed at the forum. These are education, employment, self-esteem, and youth welfare.

speech.para: We have invited young people that are either full-time or part-time students, those who work part-time or full-time, and those who are currently seeking work. This is to ensure that the outcomes of the forum are truly representative of all youth in the electorate. The issues that are to be discussed were chosen for the specific reason that the youth felt that these were the issues that were of concern to them and that the government should hear their viewpoints and ideas about them so that, when it is making decisions on these matters, young people would have some input into policies that are aimed at, or directed to, them.

Education was an obvious choice, as this is an issue which inevitably affects all youth. Another obvious choice was employment, as it is a major issue for youth today. The task force decided to call the topic `Employment'â€”which has a positive outlookâ€”rather than `Unemployment', a term which is immediately fraught with negative connotations. Self-esteem is a relatively taboo term, as there are of course ties with low self-esteem, chronic depression and, to a more serious extent, suicide. However, it must be recognised that this is a major problem for youth in our society. The fourth choice, youth welfare, is another key issue in today's society. The financial assistance offered by the government and available to youth is quite often imperative for the standard of living of young people.

Such a forum as the one that the Lilley Youth Task Force and I are holding is a vital tool to bridge the gap between young people and their parliamentary representatives. If we do not know what it is that young people need, how can we help them? The youth task force is one of many active discussion groups currently running in my electorate. These include a group for youth suicide prevention and also a group looking at finances and problems with the elderly. However, the special thing about this forum is that it will include the views of those people who live in my electorate but have not been able to have their say via the ballot box, as either they are too young or an election has not been held since they have become legally recognised as adults.

The guest speakers at the youth forum will be Dr Cheryl Hurst, who was nominated Queenslander of the Year and also received an award on Australia Day. She has done extensive research into breast cancer, and she is going to be talking to the young people on the topic of education. Mr Craig Maney from Albion McDonald's, will be talking to the young people on employment. Mike Young, who is the Olympic coach for the Australian baseball team, will be talking on self-motivation. Ben Myers, who was selected as Queensland's youth representative at the people's Constitutional Conventionâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”An outstanding young man.

â€”Thank you. He will be talking on youth welfare and the benefits that we can give young people. The main idea of this forum is to inform the government of the views of young people. I am confident that the outcomes will be positive, constructive and truly representative of what young people would like to see happening in these areas. I look forward to presenting the findings of the forum to the House, so that young people's voices will be clearly heard and so that their ideas might be a help for change in areas that are to be reviewed.

speech.para: As I said at the beginning, this speech was written by a young man in year 10 at Sandgate High School. It is always a pleasure to be able to give young people a chance to develop their skills and express their views. I congratulate Lachlan Kay on an excellent speech. I have every confidence that the youth forum will be a resounding success, when it is considered that young people of this calibre are taking an active part.

talk.start.para: â€”In the couple of minutes remaining, I wish to congratulate Kate Carnell and the ACT Liberal Party on a fine victory in the recent ACT elections. The election victory was not only a win for our side of politics but also an incredible setback for the Australian Labor Party. The ACT traditionally has been an area where the Labor Party has polled strongly. The government inherited a $10.3 billion deficit, and we had to make some very hard decisions. The Public Service has in fact had to bear the brunt of some of those decisions; yet, despite that, the ACT Liberal Party did remarkably well at the election. Graham Richardson commented on the ALP and said that behind Wayne Berry is `an organisation run by the last of the hard-line lefties.'
â€”They are over there.

â€”They are indeed! Richo said, `Go anywhere in Canberra, and people will tell you how hopeless they are. I just wish the National Executive would put an end to this farce.' He also said that ACT Labor was `led by a group of maniacs who are out of touch with the people of Canberra.'

speech.para: I would also like to congratulate Brendan Smyth, a former colleague in this place, on his election to the ACT Legislative Assembly. He will be an absolutely fine representative of the people.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Are foreign doctors entering Australia on temporary visas required to pass examination before being allowed to practice in Australia.
(2) Are there exceptions to the requirement referred to in part (1); if so, what are the exceptions.
(3) How many doctors referred to in part (1) have (a) passed examination or (b) been excepted from examination.
(4) How many overseas trained doctors entered Australia in 1996-97.
(5) From which countries did they originate.

(6) How many doctors from each country referred to in part (5) (a) entered Australia, (b) passed examination, (c) were excepted from examination and (d) applied from within Australia to extend their residency.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Foreign doctors entering Australia on temporary visas are not required to pass the Australian Medical Council examination. Temporary resident doctors are, however, required to obtain registration with the relevant State or Territory Medical Boards before practicing in Australia.
(2) There are no exceptions to the requirement referred to in the response to question (1).
(3) See response to questions (1) and (2).
(4) 898 doctors on temporary resident visas entered Australia in 1996-97.
(5) The temporary resident doctors were from the following countries:

Bangladesh, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, India, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Jordan, Malaysia, Myanmar, Namibia, Netherlands, Niger, Nigeria, Pakistan, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Poland, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Sri Lanka, St Lucia, Switzerland, Tonga, United Kingdom, United States of America and Vanuatu.
(6) (a) The following number of doctors referred to in part (5) entered Australia during 1996-97:

United Kingdom (516), Republic of Ireland (87), Canada (69), the United States of America (62), South Africa (54), India (27), France (18), Vanuatu (11), Tonga (10), Malaysia (9), Germany (7), Pakistan (3), Nigeria (2), Belgium (2), Philippines (2), Bangladesh (2), Papua New Guinea (2), Sri Lanka (1), Greece (1), Switzerland (1), Israel (1), Jordan (1), Myanmar (1), Singapore (1), St Lucia (1), Niger (1), Namibia (1), Italy (1), Spain (1), Netherlands (1), Denmark (1) and Poland (1).
(b) See response to questions (1) and (2).
(c) See response to questions (1) and (2).
(d) In 1996-97 there were 353 visas granted in Australia to temporary resident doctors seeking to extend their stay.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has he consulted the Minister for Health to determine how many non-residents or non-citizens have undergone surgical procedures using Medicare; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
(2) What statistics are available on the misuse of Medicare referred to in part (1).
(3) Do the statistics indicate the extent to which the misuse relates to medical conditions which existed before arrival in Australia.
(4) Is he able to say how many persons referred to in part (1) returned voluntarily to their country of nationality after treatment.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (4) I have asked my Department to consult with the Department of Health and Family Services (DHFS) on this matter. DHFS advises that non-residents do not have access to the Medicare arrangements except to the extent to which access is provided under the terms of a Reciprocal Health Care Arrangement.

The Health Insurance Act 1973 (HIA) defines which people are eligible for Medicare. Eligibility for Medicare is generally restricted to an `Australian resident' as defined in Section 3 of the HIA, and the person must reside in Australia. Therefore, generally, non-residents do not qualify for, nor receive access to, Medicare benefits.

No data distinguishes between access to Medicare by non-citizens as opposed to citizens, as once a person meets the definition of Australian resident in the HIA, they are an eligible person and may use Medicare.
Data regarding numbers of persons accessing surgical procedures in public hospitals are held by the States and Territories.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) How may residence/residence orders enforcing a minimum stay with either parent of 40 per cent has the Family Court issued since the Family Law Reform Act 1995 was implemented.
(2) What percentage does the figure referred to in part (1) constitute of the total number of Family Court orders issued in the same period.
(3) How many residence/residence orders have been issued since the B&B case was concluded.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Family Court has advised me that the number of residence/residence orders enforcing a minimum stay with either parent of 40 percent, issued by the Family Court of Australia since 11 June 1996 (when the Family Law Reform Act was proclaimed) is not readily available, as information about the proportional split is not entered onto the Court's case management system. However, the Family Court has further advised me that it is estimated that the total number of all residence/residence orders (including consent and other court orders) made in the period from 1 July 1996 to 28 February 1998 was 1,280.

(2) The Family Court has advised me that the total number of orders made in respect of children (including residence, contact and specific issues orders) made in the Family Court of Australia during the period from 1 July 1996 to 28 February 1998 was 76,750. The Family Court has further advised me that residence/residence orders therefore constituted approximately 1.7% of the total orders relating to children made during this period.

(3) The Family Court has advised me that the total number of residence/residence orders (including consent and other court orders) made in the Family Court of Australia since judgment in the B&B case was handed down, on 9 July 1997, to 28 February 1998 is estimated to be 470.

subdebateinfo.title: Indigenous Cultural Property: Repatriated to Australia
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2719)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister say (a) what items of indigenous cultural property have been repatriated to Australia since 1988 and (b) when, whence and in what circumstances they were repatriated.
(2) What decisions and recommendations were made concerning indigenous cultural property and archives at the 13th meeting of the Cultural Ministers Council in Adelaide on 27 February 1998.
(3) When and where will the 13th meeting of the council be held.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The return of indigenous cultural property from overseas falls within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

(2) At the 13th meeting of the Cultural Ministers Council held in Adelaide on 27 February 1998, members endorsed the approach set out in the strategic plan for the repatriation of indigenous ancestral remains and secret/sacred objects by 2001. The objectives of the strategic plan are to:
. identify where possible, the origins of all ancestral remains and secret/sacred
. objects held in museums, with records placed in national databases;
. notify all affected indigenous communities; and
. negotiate with museums and communities concerning repatriation when and
. where requested.

Ministers undertook to consider funding for the implementation of the strategy in accordance with the agreed CMC formula and agreed to report back on deliberations by 30 June 1998 or at the next Standing Committee meeting, whichever is the sooner.
(3) The 14th meeting of the Cultural Ministers Council will be held in June 1998, in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 10 March 1998:

question.para: Are harbour masters or officers in his Department empowered under federal legislation to prevent a ship from sailing if they believe that ship's master or crew are suffering from fatigue.

talk.start.para: â€”The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Harbour masters' authority is vested in them through State legislation and the honourable member should approach the relevant State authorities on this issue.
Officers of the Commonwealth Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business do not have these powers.
